    Hon. Members will remember that when the P.A.P. came into power, they created Political Secretaries in a number of Ministries. There was no creation of such a post in the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister. But in 1960 when the Political Secretary in the Ministry of Labour and Law came out into the open as a sort of rebel against the P.A.P., it was felt by the Government that his continued presence as Political Secretary in the Ministry of Labour and Law would be very embarrassing to the Government. The Government considered that his actions there were inimical to the policy of the P.A.P., and yet it did not do the right thing as it would have done had the culprit been a civil servant. He was not summarily dismissed. Instead, a special post of Political Secretary had to be created in the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister in order to contain this rebel. At that time last year, there was a lot of discussion on the creation of this post. I think it was not only explained by the Government, but some Members on the Government Bench even went to the extent of defending the holder of this post - Mr Fong Swee Suan. The post was created in this Ministry in order to contain Mr Fang Swee Suan and his continuation in this job was explained by the Government. He was defended, in fact, very vigorously. Today, Mr Fong Swee Suan is no more with the Government. Not only is he no more with the Government, but the Prime Minister in his series of

Column: 1745

awful disclosures described him as a Communist. It would appear that the Government had misused this post. The Government had felt it necessary to give public funds to a Communist.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Pro-Communists.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Or pro-Communist, whatever it is. Now that the necessity to contain a pro-Communist is no longer there, is it necessary to keep this vote in the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister? I do not think the Deputy Prime Minister would want any Political Secretary any more after his sad experience.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Everything I want to say was already said yesterday, but I would like to know - oh, no, I misunderstood.

    The Chairman: The Member is not speaking on this amendment?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: No.

    The Chairman: Mr Leong Keng Seng?

    Mr Leong Keng Seng: No.

    The Chairman: Dr Thio Chan Bee?

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): No.

    The Chairman: Inche Ahmad Jabri is not here. Dr Toh.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we have to recollect the events leading to the appointment of Mr Fong Swee Suan as my Political Secretary in chronological order. When he was appointed Political Secretary to me, he was given an opportunity to learn new subjects and to prove his qualities and ability in assisting me in my Ministry. I believe that was sometime in the middle of 1960. The Prime Minister made his series of broadcasts only a couple of months ago. Unfortunately - I must say it was a disappointment to me - my ex-Political Secretary did not prove his mettle. However, I would like to say that it does not necessarily mean that if a man could not fulfil his task

Column: 1746

in the post, therefore the post should be abolished. I think it stands on principle that it should remain, and if in the future I should find a man who will be able to assist me - and who will probably blow less hot air - on technical matters, I am prepared to appoint him as my Political Secretary.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, was it not a fact that this post was created in 1960 just to contain Mr Fong Swee Suan - to transfer him from the Ministry of Labour and Law to the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: That was related in the debate on the Estimates for 1960 and I do not want to go back to history.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I take it that the answer is yes. Therefore, since the man is no longer there to be contained, why keep the vote?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: As I have pointed out to the Member for Cairnhill, the post is already there and if the man does not prove his worth, it is up to me to find another man to fill the post. If the man has not proved his worth, it does no necessarily mean the post ought to be abolished. May I give the hon. Member a simple example? There is a post--the elected representative of Cairnhill. If the Member for Cairnhill does not prove his worth, it does not necessarily mean that we should abolish that post.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, as regards the manner and the moment of the creation of this post, it is quite clear to the House that it was created in order that the Deputy Prime Minister, who is the mildest gentleman in the P.A.P., could deal with Mr Fang Swee Suan who was getting very difficult, because you know, Mr Speaker, Sir, that when trouble brews in the P.A.P., it is the Chairman who sorts it all out because he is such a gentleman. It was this quality in the Deputy Prime Minister that persuaded the Prime Minister to transfer Mr Fong Swee Suan from the Ministry of Labour, where he had to deal with the present Minister for Health, to; the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister. But, unfortunately, no

Column: 1747

such post existed. Therefore, the Government created the post without reference to the Assembly because it had to be done quickly on a Special Warrant, and Mr Fong Swee Suan was put there. It is fairly certain and as clear as the nose on one's face that the post was created specially to contain Mr Fang Swee Suan. It was never the intention of the Government to have a Political Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister because, if one looks at the departments under the Deputy Prime Minister, it is quite clear that there is not much point in appointing a Political Secretary. I think even the Deputy Prime Minister will admit that.

    My other point is that Mr Fong Swee Suan has left the Government and has left the Party.

    An hon. Member: He will come back.

    Mr Rajah: Well, if he comes back, that will be the time for the Minister to come back to the House for an approval of the vote. I ask the Minister for Finance to follow Establishment practice in these matters, which is this: if the use for the post has disappeared, then the post must be abolished. The use for this post has certainly disappeared, and I ask the Minister for Finance how he, in fairness to the finances of the country, can tolerate this post in the Budget. We know what a strict Minister for Finance he is. We know how difficult he is with the Establishment Branch on posts. Therefore, he should apply the same yardstick to this matter. He is not concerned with the politics of the P.A.P. He is the Finance Minister of the State of Singapore. I will tell him this: if he carries redundant posts in the Budget, it merely means that sums of money which could be available for social services and such like valuable objects arc being denied. Can the Minister for Finance tolerate such a situation?

    Mr Low Por Tuck (Havelock): Mr Speaker. Sir, was there any work actually given to the ex-Political Secretary?

    Mr Rajaratnam rose -

Column: 1748



    The Chairman: Is the Minister for Culture sharing in this debate? If he wishes to do so, he can do so. Mr Rajaratnam.

    Mr Rajaratnam: This is going to be a recurring subject. I myself will be sooner or later involved. It is just as well to dispose of it at this moment. There are two points. If I remember correctly, when this business of Political Secretaries was discussed earlier on, I think it was made quite clear that in principle every Minister was going to have a Political Secretary because, as had been explained, the function of a Political Secretary was to assist Ministers in the political aspect of their work. To that extent, if at any particular time a Minister does or does not have a Political Secretary, it does not mean that he should not have one at some subsequent date when he feels that he can get a man more suited to the post. The other point is this. It is not necessarily true that just because Mr Fong Swee Suan failed very badly in the technical job to which he was assigned, that the job should be abolished. As you know, Sir, I think five Parliamentary Secretaries have also defected. It does not mean that we should abolish the posts of Parliamentary Secretary. In fact, there was a time when four or five Ministers had no Parliamentary Secretaries for a while.

2.45 p.m

    So the fact that the post is vacant at any particular time does not necessarily mean that there is no need for its existence, because if and when we can find a suitable man to fill it we will certainly do so.

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister has quite nicely suggested that Mr Fang Swee Suan was transferred to his Ministry because he was to be given training in the technical aspects of his Ministry. But I think the Member for Farrer Park has made his point, that there is practically nothing, as far as I can see, in the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister which calls for a Political Secretary's post, having regard to the sort of work that Political

Column: 1749

Secretaries in the Ministry of Labour and Law and the Ministry of Education are doing. I do not want to labour this point. All that I am trying to do is to put this question of Political Secretary in its proper perspective so that, as the Minister for Culture has said, when we come to the next Head and discuss Political Secretaries, we may understand what it is all about.

    To start off with this question of Political Secretaries -

    The Chairman: Order. I think the Member for Thomson was here when we discussed this same topic under the Prime Minister's Ministry, and I did indicate that two aspects of the topic had to be discussed and disposed of yesterday. The first was the principle as to why Political Secretaries are necessary. That has been disposed of. The other point is the increase of $250 in salary. That too has been disposed of. Now we are dealing with any reason why a Political Secretary is required in any Ministry, and we have come to the Deputy Prime Minister's Ministry. That is the subject of debate now.

    Mr Bani: I just want to say things that are related to what has transpired so far as Mr Fong Swee Suan is concerned. In the first place, Sir, Mr Fong Swee Suan was not transferred from the Ministry of Labour and Law because he needed technical training. He was transferred because he criticised the Government's labour policy when he spoke as a trade unionist at a trade union meeting. The Government did not have the guts to sack him because they knew that if they sacked him they would lose the confidence of the workers. So what they did was quietly to transfer him to some place where he would be considered least harmful to the Government. Mr Lim Ching Siong was already Political Secretary in the Ministry of Finance where they thought he would be least harmful. So they could not have Mr Fong Swee Suan in the Ministry of Finance, and their next obvious choice was the Ministry of the Deputy Prime Minister. Therefore, Sir, the question of Political Secretaryship in the Ministry of the Deputy Prime

Column: 1750

Minister was purely for the purpose of accommodating Mr Fong Swee Suan. Now Mr Fang Swee Suan is no more in the P.A.P., and I do not think Mr Jek Yuen Thong or Inche Rahim Ishak, the two Political Secretaries at the moment, would ever be required to take a transfer on the same basis as Mr Fong took. Even if that happened, Sir, the post of Political Secretary in the Ministry of Finance being vacant, I therefore do not think there is any need to have the post contained.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Member for Thomson has said, if Mr Fong Swee Suan had felt unhappy in my Ministry as Political Secretary, and if it was thought that the idea was to contain him, then the obvious step for him to take would have been to pack up instead of accepting the post.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I am far from being certain, Mr Speaker, Sir, that a Political Secretary is not necessary in the Deputy Prime Minister's Ministry. You will recollect that a week go - or was it two weeks ago? - when the postmen decided at a meeting to call a strike, I would suggest, Mr Speaker, Sir, that if Mr Fang Swee Suan had been in harness, that incident could well have been averted. So I think the argument -

    Mr Rajah: The Minister's argument?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: One way or the other. Whenever you deal with a large labour force, there are matters in which various officers in the Deputy Prime Minister's Ministry are involved in public relations.

    As regards the question raised by the Member for Havelock, whether Mr Fong Swee Suan did or did not do any work, I cannot speak for the particular gentleman, but I do know what happened to my own Political Secretary.

    The Chairman: Order. Perhaps the Minister will let us know about that when we come to his Ministry.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: So be it.

Column: 1751



    Mr Rajah: Sir, I was hoping that the Minister for Finance would answer the question, if he was satisfied that this post was not likely to be filled, or that there was no reason to believe that this post could be filled, or that there was anybody in the offing who could fill that post, whether he, as Minister for Finance, would not see to, it that this post be deleted from the Estimates. Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the main difficulty in this matter is this, that the Government is taking a particular stand on this. They made the first move in this. Right. The whole thing has gone wrong and, if I may use the Finance Minister's own expression - a suitable expression - the Government is in a state of "zugzwang". Any single move they make with regard to Political Secretaries would be a wrong move. So the Minister for Finance, who is a chess player, is in a state of "zugzwang". He refuses to carry out his duties as Minister for Finance and allows this appointment to continue. Sir, it is quite pointless tying up in this manner public money which could otherwise be spent usefully. Sir, I would like to hear the Minister for Finance on the tying up of money which could be utilised for other public purposes. This is a serious proposition which I put to the Minister in order to help his Government save its face - hundreds of thousands of dollars are being denied for public use.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I must answer the Member for Farrer Park. I do not want him to refer to the Minister for Finance because I also have to take the responsibility.

    I give this House this assurance: if by the end of the next financial year I am not able to find somebody who is able to act as my Political Secretary and be a good public relations officer between my Ministry and the public, then when the subsequent Budget comes, I will see that that post is not kept in my Ministry.

    An hon. Member: There is no -

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (Upper Serangoon)(In Mandarin): I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister a question on this item. As far as I can see, the creation of the post of Political Secretary in the Deputy Prime Minister's Office can have only one use - if there is any - and that is to assist in the design of postage stamps. In this respect, there may be some political colour; for example, on National Day we have a stamp design. I wonder whether the Deputy Prime Minister has consulted his Political Secretary in this respect.

    The Chairman: Time is getting on.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin (Nee Soon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I heard the Deputy Prime Minister assure us that when we come to the Budget for 1963, if he does not have any use for his Political Secretary, he will consider deleting that post. Might I remind him that we are coming to that Budget in a few days' time?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Barisan Sosialis have got the facts wrong. We are not considering the 1963 Budget. It is a Vote on Account. It is different from the Budget.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, in view of the assurance given by the Deputy Prime Minister, may I beg leave to withdraw?

    Sir, because procedure requires that I cannot say anything if I do not wish to move an amendment, I have taken the liberty of moving one in order to explain that I have given notice of a number of amendments of a similar character. The first amendment was in respect of the Ministry of the Prime Minister, when the Minister for Finance explained that there had been some reorganisation in the civil service, and that there had been some upgrading and downgrading. Therefore, in cases where I am satisfied

that it was as a result of that exercise, I will not move my amendment. I now beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    The Chairman: After that long speech, any Member may speak if he wishes to. I am not preventing any Member from speaking. No one wishes to speak.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 12 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 3.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I am calling upon the Member for the Southern Islands to move it.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 12 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 3.

    This concerns entertainment expenses. In 1961 $3,000 was voted for, and for 1962 $4,000. There is an increase of $1,000. I observe there are no increases in entertainment expenses in other Ministries. The increase appears only in this Ministry. So I would like to know why the increase of $1,000 is needed, and I believe all other Members would also like to know.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I do agree there has been an increase of $1,000 in entertainment expenses under my Head. This is a personal application which I made to the Finance Minister, and the explanation is very simple. In my capacity as Deputy Prime Minister, I have to receive Ministers and statesmen from overseas. Being also in charge of several technical departments and the Polytechnic, I have to meet technicians and professional people who come to Singapore either to advise me or to offer material assistance to my departments or to the Polytechnic. Under these circumstances, I have found from my experience that the sum of $3,000 was quite inadequate. In fact, this year with the Air Show I was pretty hard up. There were many people whom I ought to have entertained rather than

Column: 1754

just merely shaking their hands and accepting material assistance. I felt quite ashamed.

3.00 p.m.

You know, Mr Speaker, that not a single cent enters my pocket because this money comes under a vote. Since I am going to get another $1,000 under entertainment expenses, if any Member on the opposite benches wants me to entertain them, they are welcome, provided they can give me technical assistance!

A sum of money is required for travelling expenses incurred by my Office and by my Parliamentary Secretary. As you are aware, Mr Speaker, particularly with changes going on in my departments, which are largely of a pan-Malayan character, there is a considerable amount of discussion which has to be held between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. Sometimes it necessitates frequent trips to Kuala Lumpur for my officials and myself to discuss with our counterparts there.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 13 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of subhead 1.

    Sir, about five years ago, all political Parties in Singapore accepted the principle of Malayanisation. At that time, the present Minister for Health and Law played a very predominant part in demanding that Malayanisation be introduced as speedily as possible. It was felt, however, Sir, that in certain posts it might be necessary to retain expatriate officers until local officers were trained. Another principle was also mentioned, that as soon as a local officer could be put in, the expatriate officer could still be retained as a supernumerary officer or as an advisory officer.

    Sir, the post of Director of Civil Aviation was vacated by the expatriate officer at that time. I believe the replacement was also an expatriate officer. We are not saying that the successor is not able to do the job. But if we are going to follow the policy of Malayanisation, will the Government explain whether there are not suitable local officers who can fill that post? If it is necessary for the present expatriate officer to be retained, cannot he be retained as a supernumerary officer?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, as far as the policy of Malayanisation is concerned, I can assure the House that I am one of its champions. In fact, I have exerted my utmost to malayanise as many posts as possible in the departments under my charge. Now, with reference to the particular post mentioned by the Member for Tanglin - the post of Director of Civil Aviation. I must give him this information in case he speaks out of ignorance. The present Director of Civil Aviation was seconded to the Singapore Government by the Australian Government. His period of secondment will expire in June 1962.

As far as the present incumbent of the post is concerned, I can convince the Member for Tanglin that he is only too happy to go back to his post in Australia, because otherwise he will lose benefits in terms of pension and so on. We have just now two officers who are being trained and groomed for the post of Director of Civil Aviation. A report on their capabilities will subsequently be submitted to the Public Service Commission. It will be the P.S.C. who will ultimately decide which one of these trainees will be suitable to fill the post of Director of Civil Aviation.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the assurance given, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 13 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (2) of subhead 1.

    Sir, in this particular case, it is a downgrading of a post. An Airport Signals Officer drawing a salary scale of Code I-10 is now regraded as Administrative Assistant drawing a salary scale of Code I-25. That is to say, it is on a lower salary scale. Although the starting point is still the same at $680 a month, the maximum is different. In the case of the higher salary scale, the maximum is $1,420. In the case of the lower salary scale, the maximum is $1,030. Sir, I bring this point up in order to find out from the Minister the procedure adopted in downgrading a post. Does the holder of the post of Airport Signals Officer automatically become an Administrative Assistant on a lower scale?

    The Chairman: Has the Member for Cairnhill looked at the correct items? The bracketed items are the "Administrative Officer" and "Administrative Assistant".

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I am sorry. When I said "Airport Signals Officer", I mean Administrative Officer to Administrative Assistant.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, this is part of the question which the Member for Cairnhill asked yesterday with regard to Principal Assistant Secretary. It is all part of the scheme to reorganise the civil service. If the Minister for Finance were here, he could explain the reorganisation much more clearly than I can. However, I have a script down here which explains what is required of an Administrative Assistant. This is a trainee grade where new recruits to the Administrative Service obtain training and guidance from senior officers, and a knowledge of as wide as possible a range of government activities and structure. They will normally be attached to more senior officers as assistants, with the minimum of specified duties, but they will have an opportunity to learn other work for which they may be expected to have responsibility in the future. There may well be periods in which they are charged with duties in an executive field. They will be expected to serve as Secretary in Committee, to prepare draft papers bearing on matters of policy for consideration by senior officers, and to carry out research leading to the presentation of facts and comments on existing situations. They will often be concerned with the detailed study of legislation.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister has said a lot of things which do not even answer the simple question asked by me. What I ask is this - here we have an Administrative Officer on a higher scale. Then we reduce his scale to a lower scale. How do we carry it out? Do we ask the Administrative Officer to become an Administrative Assistant and shut his mouth and make him get a lower pay? What is the procedure adopted? Is it because the Administrative Officer drawing that salary has already left the post, and, therefore, the post has been renamed "Administrative Assistant"? Is it that a new entrant has come into the service, and not that the holder of the Administrative Officer post has been forcibly asked to take on

Column: 1758

the job as Administrative Assistant on a lower scale, which means a reduction of nearly $300 in the maximum?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, when we had an expatriate service, there used to be what were known as the Administrative Service and the Administrative Officer grades, the former a fully administrative grade and the latter a semi-administrative grade, the officers of which were known as Administrative Officers. They were all expatriate officers. The grade of Administrative Officer has been abolished and we have regraded the Administrative service, timescale.
